questions.text: Demography- the scientific study of the human population consists of the following demographic processes A/E
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Morbidity Demography- The scientific study of the human population. It focuses on three readily observable human phenomena – change in population size, composition, and distribution. It deals with five demographic processes , namely: Fertility Mortality Marriage Migration Social mobility

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the ‘Late expanding phase of the demographic cycle’ is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Birth rate is lower than the death rate

options.label: B
options.text: Death rate begins to decline while birth rate remains unchanged

options.label: C
options.text: Death rate declines more than the birth rate

options.label: D
options.text: High death rate and high birth rate

questions.correct_answer: C. Death rate declines more than the birth rate
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Death rate declines more than the birth rate The history of world population since 1650 suggests that there is a demographic cycle of 5 stages through which a nation passes: (1) FIRST STAGE (High stationary) It is characterized by both A high birth rate and A high death rate Therefore they both cancel each other, and the population remains stationary. It is seen when the country is economically weak. India was in this stage till 1920 (2) SECOND STAGE (Early expanding) It begins with the Declining in death rate while The birth rate remains high/unchanged. As a result, a huge increase in population occurs. The DR decline is mainly due to improvements in the food supply, health care, and sanitation. At present many developing countries in Asia and Africa is in this stage. The BRs have increased in some of these countries probably because of the following: Improved health care provisions, and Shortening periods of breast-feeding (3) THIRD STAGE (Late expanding) Death rate declines further and The birth rate now begins to fall. However, as the BR still exceeds the DR, there is an increase in the population. The fall in BR results mostly from access to contraceptives, women empowerment, India appears to be at this stage. In some developing countries (e.g., China, Singapore), birth rates have declined fast. (4) FOURTH STAGE (Low stationary) This stage is characterized with Low birth rate and Low death rate. Consequently, the population remains stationary. An aging population is a feature of this stage. Japan, Sweden, Belgium, Denmark, and Switzerland are in this stage. Most industrialized countries have undergone a demographic transition. From a high BR and high DR To low BR and low DR Zero population growth was recorded in Austria during 1980- 85. Growth rate as low as 0.1 was recorded in the UK, Denmark, Sweden, and Belgium during 1980-85. (5) FIFTH STAGE: (Declining) Birth rate is now lower than the death rate. Hence the population begins to decline Some East European countries (e.g., Germany, and Hungary) and some North European countries (e.g., Sweden, Norway) are now in this stage

questions.text: Match the following stages of the demographic cycle with their correct description: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I High Stationary High Birth rate & High Death rate Early expanding Death rate starts falling but Birth rate remains high Low stationary Birth rate & Death rate both are at low level Declining stage Birth rate is less than Death rate

questions.text: Demographic transition refers to the process of transition from-

options.label: A
options.text: High Birth rate & low Death rate to Low Birth Rate & High Death Rate

options.label: B
options.text: High Birth rate & Death rate to Low Birth rate & Death rate

options.label: C
options.text: Low Birth rate & Death rate to High Birth rate & Death rate

options.label: D
options.text: High Death Rate & low Birth rate to Low Death rate & High Birth Rate

questions.correct_answer: B. High Birth rate & Death rate to Low Birth rate & Death rate
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High Birth rate & Death rate to Low Birth rate & Death rate The history of world population since 1650 suggests that there is a demographic cycle of 5 stages through which a nation passes. Demographic transition refers to the process of transition of a nation from high birth and death rate to a state of Low Birth & Death rate as shown in the following demographic transition model-

questions.text: The year 1921 is known as the year of the big divide for India. The reason for it is?

options.label: A
options.text: India moved out of stage 1 after 1921

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing number of people were subsequently added after 1921

options.label: C
options.text: Marked diversification of population was achieved after 1921

questions.correct_answer: B. Increasing number of people were subsequently added after 1921
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increasing number of people were subsequently added after 1921 India is the second most populous country in the world, next only to China. India’s population has been steadily increasing since 1921. The year 1921 is called the big divide because the absolute number of people added to the population during each decade has been on the increase since 1921. Till 1921, India was in stage 1(high stationary stage) of the demographic cycle. Since 1921, it has moved from stage 1 into stage III (late expanding).

questions.text: The period between when the dependency ratio decreases because of decreasing fertility till when it starts to rise because of increasing longevity is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Demographic bonus Demographic bonus is the period when the dependency ratio in a population declines because of a decline in fertility until it starts to rise again because of increasing longevity. The rapid decrease in the child dependency ratio is identified as an important factor underlying rapid economic development. Demographic burden denotes the increase in total dependency ratio during any period of time caused by an increased old-age dependency ratio. Demographic transition is a phenomenon that refers to a shift from a high birth rate and high death rate to a low birth rate and low death rate.

questions.text: Contraction of demographic Gap starts in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Early stage III

questions.text: Demographic Gap attains its maximum limit in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Late Stage II Stage of demographic cycle Meaning E.g First stage Second stage High stationary Early expanding High Birth rate (BR) & high Death rate (DR) which cancels each other and the population remains stationary. DR decreasing but BR high India till 1920 SEA, Africa Third stage Late expanding DR decreasing still further BR also starts declining. The population continues to grow as BR>DR. India Forth stage Low stationary Low BR & low DR. Population is stationary UK, Denmark, Sweden, Belgium. Fifth stage Declining BR < DR. Population is decreasing Germany, Hungary

questions.text: In the context of demography, the term “Demographic Burden” is used to connote:
questions.correct_answer: B. Increase in total dependency ratio
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in total dependency ratio The ratio of children 0-14 years & older population >65 years of age to the population of the economically productive age group of 15-64 years is referred to as the dependency ratio. The term “demographic burden” is used to connote the increase in total dependency ratio during any period of time, mostly caused by increased old-age dependency ratio. As the health infrastructure of any country improves, longevity increases which ultimately leads to an increase in old age and total dependency ratio. This is an inevitable consequence of demographic transition, and the country has to face it sooner or later.

questions.text: The estimated Birth Rate and Death Rate of India in 2020 is 18.2 per 1000 population and 7.3 per 1000 population respectively. As a public health expert which of the following interpretations would you draw from this data?

options.label: A
options.text: India is undergoing explosive population growth currently

options.label: B
options.text: The current population growth in India is very slow

options.label: C
options.text: There is rapid population growth in India

options.label: D
options.text: Population in India is in stationary phase

questions.correct_answer: C. There is rapid population growth in India
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is rapid population growth in India When the crude death rate is subtracted from the crude birth rate, the net residual is the currentannual growth rate, exclusive of migration. The relation between growth rate and the population is shown in the table below- Rating Annual rate of growth % Number of years required for the population to double in size Stationary population No growth Slow growth Less than 0.5 More than 139 Moderate growth 0.5 to 1.0 139-70 Rapid growth 1.0 to 1.5 70-47 Very Rapid growth 1.5 to 2.0 47-35 Explosive growth 2.0 to 2.5 35-28 ----------”------------ 2.5 to 3.0 28-23 ----------”------------ 3.0 to 3.5 23-20 ----------”------------ 3.5 to 4.0 20-18 So, as per this table we can conclude that there is rapid population growth in India.

questions.text: If the annual growth rate of the population ranges between 1 to 1.5 percent, the number of years required by the country to double its population would be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

47 – 70 yrs If Growth Rate = 1.5 = 70 / 1.5 = 47 At Growth Rate = 1 = 70 Ans = 47- 70 Doubling Time Doubling time = the number of years it would take a population to double its size at its current growth rate.

questions.text: The ratio of the combined age group 0 – 14 years plus 65 years and above to the 15 – 65 years age group is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Total dependency ratio The proportion of persons above 65 years and children below 15 years are considered to be dependent on the economically productive age group (15 – 64 years). The ratio of the combined age group 0-14 years plus 65 years and above to the 15 – 65 years age group is referred to as the total dependency ratio. This is also known as the societal dependency ratio. The dependency ratio is further divided into young age dependency ratio (0 – 14 years) and old age dependency ratio (65 years and above).

questions.text: The shape of the age pyramid for India is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Triangle shaped The age pyramid, also known as the population pyramid, is a graphical representation of the population with various age distributions on the y-axis and percentages on the x-axis. The graph shows male and female population percentages in all age groups by dividing the x-axis into male and female, with males on the left side and females on the right side. The age pyramid of India is typical of any other developing country with a broad base and a tapering top, hence appearing as a triangle. This means that India has a higher percentage of children and young individuals, and as the age increases, the percentage decreases. India has a very less percentage of the geriatric population. In developed countries, the pyramid shows a bulge in the middle and has a narrow base.

questions.text: In Village A with a total population of 1 Lakh, Among them, 20% population are below 15 years of age, and 60000 are People between 15-64yr of age. What is the Total Dependency Ratio of Village A?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

66.6 Percent Total Population of Village A = 1 Lakh Population between 0-14 years = 20000 Population between 15-64 years = 60000 Population between 65 years and above = 20000 Since,

questions.text: In a Village in India, having a total population of 100000. The total number of children from the age of 0-6 years is 30000. The total number of persons> 7 years old who can read and write and can understand in their own language is 40000. What is the effective literacy rate of the given Village?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

57.1 Percent Total Population of Village = 100000 Since, Total Number of children from age 0-6 = 30000 Therefore, Total Number of the population above 7 years of age = 70000 Total Number of people among >7 years of age and literate = 40000 So,

questions.text: Which of the following is the only indicator that considers fertility as well as mortality situation in society?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Net reproduction rate Net reproduction rate: Defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime, assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.

questions.text: The following method calculates the failure rate of a contraceptive for each month of use:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Life table analysis Life-table analysis : Life-table analysis calculates a failure rate for each month of use. A cumulative failure rate can then compare methods for any specific length of exposure. Women who leave a study for any reason other than unintended pregnancy are removed from the analysis, contributing to their exposure until the time of the exit. The Pearl index is usually based on a specific exposure (usually one year) and, therefore, fails to compare methods at various durations of exposure accurately. This limitation is overcome by using the method of life-table analysis. Couple protection rate is the number of couples effectively using contraception methods. Net reproduction rate is the number of daughters born to a woman taking into account mortality.

questions.text: The magnitude of completed family size can be measured by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TFR TFR: Total Fertility Rate It represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing a child at the same rate as the women now in each age group. This gives a measurement of the completed family size. It is calculated by summing the age-specific fertility rate for all ages. GFR: General Fertility Rate It is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year. It is a better measure of fertility than crude birth rate because the denominator is restricted to the number of women in the child bearing age group. GMFR: General Marital Fertility Rate It is the number of live births per 1000 married women in the reproductive age group in a given year. It is more specific than GFR. ASFR: Age Specific Fertility Rate It is the number of live births in a particular age group per 1000 mid-year female population of the same age group. It is a more precise measurement of fertility. It reflects the fertility pattern.

questions.text: The average number of girls born to a woman, if she experiences the current fertility pattern, is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gross reproduction rate GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate): It is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span (15 – 45 years) , assuming no mortality. Net Reproduction rate (NRR): Number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime, assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates. Child-woman ratio: it is the number of children 0 – 4 years of age per 1000 women of childbearing This ratio is used where birth registration statistics either do not exist or are inadequate. Pregnancy rate: it is the ratio of the number of pregnancies in a year to the married women in the age group 15 – 44 years.

questions.text: Which of the following statement about GFR is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the number of live births per 1000 married women of reproductive age group

options.label: B
options.text: CBR is a better measure of fertility than GFR

options.label: C
options.text: GFR is a better measure of fertility than CBR

questions.correct_answer: C. GFR is a better measure of fertility than CBR
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GFR is a better measure of fertility than CBR GFR: General Fertility Rate It is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year. It is a better measure of fertility than crude birth rate because the denominator is restricted to the number of women in the childbearing age group CBR: Crude Birth Rate Number of live births per 1000 estimated mid-year population in a given year. It is an unsatisfactory measure of fertility because the total population is not exposed to childbearing hence, it doesn’t give a true idea of the population's fertility.

questions.text: All of the following are Fertility indicators EXCEPT-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gross Fertility Rate The fertility indicator is Gross Reproduction Rate, not Gross Fertility Rate. It is defined as the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality. Other fertility indicators of importance are: General Fertility Rate, General Marital Fertility Rate, Age-specific Fertility Rate, Age-specific Marital Fertility Rate, Total Fertility Rate, Total Marital Fertility Rate, Net Reproduction Rate, Child Woman ratio

questions.text: As a Public Health Programme manager, you have to estimate the General Fertility Rate of a district to analyze the fertility trends. What data would you require for its estimation?

options.label: A
options.text: Number of live births in a year & mid-year population

options.label: B
options.text: Number of live births in a year & Mid-year female population in reproductive age group

options.label: C
options.text: Number of live girl child born in a year & Mid-year female population in reproductive age group

options.label: D
options.text: Number of marriages in a year & mid-year population

questions.correct_answer: B. Number of live births in a year & Mid-year female population in reproductive age group
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Number of live births in a year & Mid-year female population in reproductive age group General Fertility rate is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group ( 15-44 or 49 years) in a given year. It is considered a better measure of fertility than the crude birth rate because the denominator is restricted to the number of women in the childbearing age group.

questions.text: Read the following statements about Net Reproduction Rate and choose the most appropriate response- A. It is defined as the number of male children a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime, assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates B. NRR of 1 is equivalent to attaining approximately the 2-child norm C. If NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be higher than the replacement level. D. If the Couple Protection Rate is 60%, then NRR=1 Select the correct answer from given below code:

options.label: D
options.text: All the above statements are correct

questions.explanation:
Solution:

B & D are correct It is defined as the number of girl children a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates NRR of 1 is equivalent to attaining approximately the 2-child norm If NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be lower than the replacement level. If the Couple Protection Rate is 60%, then NRR=1 . CPR is based on the observation that 50-60% of births in a year are of the birth order 3 or more. Thus attaining a 60% CPR will be equivalent to cutting off almost all third or higher-order births, leaving 2 or less surviving children per couple. So, only statements B & D are correct.

questions.text: As per NFHS-V, the total Fertility Rate of India is 2.0; assuming no mortality & current fertility pattern, what will be the Gross Reproduction Rate of India?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 Gross Reproduction Rate (GRR) is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality. Total Fertility Rate represents the average number of children a woman in her reproductive age group would have. It is assumed that the chances of having a girl child to any couple is 50%, that is ½. So, Gross Reproduction Rate = ½ * TFR Hence, GRR= ½ * 2 = 1

questions.text: For finding out the prevalence of the contraceptive practice in a community which of the following indicators may be used-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Couple Protection Rate Couple Protection Rate is an indicator of the prevalence of contraceptive practice in the community. It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved family planning methods. Pearl Index is used to measure the efficacy of contraceptives and not Prevalence. It is defined as the contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). Birth rate is the number of live births per 1000 estimated mid-year population in a given year Age-specific marital fertility rate is the number of live births in a year to 1000 married women in any specified age group.

questions.text: The incorrect statement regarding Couple Protection Rate is-

options.label: A
options.text: It is an indicator of the prevalence of contraceptive practice in the community

options.label: B
options.text: NRR=1 can be achieved only when CPR is ≥50%

options.label: C
options.text: It is the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved family planning methods

questions.correct_answer: B. NRR=1 can be achieved only when CPR is ≥50%
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NRR=1 can be achieved only when CPR is ≥50% Couple Protection Rate or CPR is an indicator of the prevalence of the contraceptive practice in the community. It is the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning If the Couple Protection Rate is 60%, then NRR=1. CPR is based on the observation that 50-60% of births in a year are of the birth order 3 or more. Thus, attaining a 60% CPR will be equivalent to cutting off almost all third or higher-order births, leaving 2 or less surviving children per couple.

questions.text: In Town A, 150 women were using X contraceptives for a continuous period of 3 years. During this 3-year period, 50 women conceived despite using the X contraceptive during this period. What is the Perl Index of the given X contraceptive?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

11.11 per HWY PEARL INDEX (PI) defined as the number of failures of contraceptive per 100 women years of exposure (HWY). In the given question, Total accidental pregnancies = 50 Total months of exposure = 150 couples × 36 months each = 5400 months Thus, PI =( 50/5400) × 1200 = 11.11 per HWY

questions.text: As a Public Health Specialist, you want to assess the contraceptive efficacy of a certain contraceptive method. During a period of 1 year, 2 unintended pregnancies occur among 100 women in the area. What is the contraceptive efficacy of this method of contraception?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 HWY Contraceptive efficacy is calculated by Pearl Index. Pearl Index of 2 means a failure rate of 2 per 100 women years of use or 2 accidental pregnancies per 100 women years of use. Since, the average reproductive period of women is 25 years, the Pearl index of 2 HWY means 0.5 accidental pregnancies will occur if a woman uses this particular contraceptive the method for the entire reproductive period. The higher the Pearl Index, the lower the effectiveness & higher the failure rate of the contraceptive method.

questions.text: A study conducted on reproductive Health concluded that many women who are sexually active would avoid becoming pregnant but nevertheless are not using any method of contraception due to inconvenience, lack of information, and fears about contraception. The term used to describe this phenomenon is-
questions.correct_answer: D. Unmet need for family planning
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unmet need for family planning Women with an unmet need for family planning are those who are fecund and sexually active but are not using any method of contraception, and report not wanting any more children or wanting to delay the next child. The concept of unmet need points to the gap between women’s reproductive intentions and their contraceptive behaviour.

questions.text: As a public health doctor working in Reproductive and Child Health, you have to work on the calculation of Life table analysis in a district. This is done for assessing-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Efficacy of contraceptives Contraceptive efficacy is generally assessed by measuring the number of unplanned pregnancies that occur during a specified period of exposure and use of a contraceptive method. Two methods have been used to measure contraceptive efficacy- Pearl Index & Life table analysis. Life table analysis calculates a failure rate for each month of use. A cumulative failure rate can then compare methods for any specific length of exposure. Women who leave a study for any reason other than unintended pregnancy are removed from the analysis, contributing to their exposure until the time of the exit. Women with unmet needs for family planning are those who are fecund and sexually active but are not using any method of contraception and report not wanting any more children or wanting to delay the next child. Couple Protection rate is an indicator of the prevalence of the contraceptive practice in the community. It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning. Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) is defined as the number of girl children a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates

questions.text: “GATHER APPROACH” is applied for:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contraceptive counselling It is imperative to help women and their spouses to gain increased control over their reproductive health. Special emphasis is placed on interpersonal communication (IPC) and the use of traditional local media for increased acceptance and understanding of messages and, thereby, their effect and impact through behavior change. GATHER APPROACH is used for contraceptive counselling: There are 6 steps to it- G – Greet clients in a friendly manner A – Ask their contraceptive requirements by asking open-ended questions T – Tell them about available options under the RCH program. H – Help them choose the method most suitable to them by providing correct information E – Explain the use, side effects (if any), and failure rate of the method chosen R – Return visit & follow-up advice.

questions.text: The term “Cafeteria Approach” applies to-

options.label: A
options.text: Choice of contraceptives in Family planning

questions.correct_answer: A. Choice of contraceptives in Family planning
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Choice of contraceptives in Family planning “Cafeteria Approach” has been adopted by the Family Welfare Programme since the In this, clients are provided with a choice of contraceptive methods. It provides the clients with a basket of choices that includes five official methods: i. Female sterilization ii. Male sterilization iii. IUCD iv. OCPs v. Condoms This approach recognizes that different people have different needs based on age, family size preferences, economic conditions, religion, and other factors. Cafeteria Approach emphasizes on limitation of family size rather than contraception.

questions.text: The correct regimen for Chhaya is?

options.label: D
options.text: Twice a week for 1st 3 months, then once a week

questions.correct_answer: D. Twice a week for 1st 3 months, then once a week
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Twice a week for 1st 3 months, then once a week Chhaya: composed of centchroman (ormeloxifene), which is a non-hormonal, non-steroidal, non-carcinogenic, non-teratogenic It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. Acts by increasing the movement of the fertilized ovum through the fallopian tube. It is taken twice a week for 1st 3 months and once a week after that. The failure rate is 1 – 2 per 100 women years.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an oral contraceptive pill supplied under National Family Planning Programme?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antara Under National Family Planning Programme, the following Oral Contraceptive Pills are supplied Free of cost – Mala N: Combined Oral Contraceptive Pill Chhaya: Centchroman containing non-hormonal oral contraceptive pill Ezy Pill: Levonorgestrel containing Emergency contraceptive pill in the public sector Antara is an injectable hormonal contraceptive containing Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA) supplied free of cost under National Family Planning Programme.

questions.text: The duration of protection provided by the following contraceptive is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3 months The given image is of Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate, an injectable contraceptive. A standard dose of 150 mg gives protection from pregnancy in 99% of women for at least 3 months . Due to this reason, it has been found to be a safe, effective, and acceptable contraceptive that requires a minimum of motivation or none at all.

questions.text: Lactating mothers should be advised to take Medroxyprogesterone Acetate as a contraceptive –

options.label: D
options.text: Should not be given when breastfeeding

questions.explanation:
Solution:

After 6 weeks post-partum Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (MPA) is a suitable choice for breastfeeding mothers. It does not affect the quality and quantity of breast milk. However, it should be started only after 6 weeks postpartum . If she is fully or nearly fully breastfeeding and her monthly bleeding has not returned, then there is no need for a backup method for contraception . The reason for not giving Injectable -MPA to breastfeeding mothers during the first 6 weeks postpartum is due to a theoretical risk of the infant getting exposed to the steroid hormone, which the newborn's immature system may not be able to metabolize (WHO MEC -5th edition 2015). Injection MPA has a higher dose of the hormone, as compared to POPs, which contain a very less amount of progestin.

questions.text: All of the following are barrier methods of contraception EXCEPT-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Yuzpe method The aim of the barrier or occlusive method of contraception is to prevent live sperm from meeting the ovum. They act as barriers in the deposition of semen into the female reproductive tract, thereby preventing pregnancy. Barrier methods of contraception include the following: Physical Methods: i. Condom ii. Diaphragm iii. Vaginal Sponge Chemical Methods (Spermicides): i. Foams ii. Creams, jellies, pastes iii. Suppositories iv. Soluble films Yuzpe method is an emergency contraceptive method wherein 2 Combined Estrogen-progesterone pill is given 12 hours apart within 72 hours of unprotected sexual intercourse. So, it is NOT a barrier method of contraception.

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate response with respect to the method of contraception depicted in the given figure. A. It is a barrier method of contraception B. It gives additional protection from STDs C. It has a lower failure rate as compared to OCPs D. It is made up of latex and is relatively cheaper as compared to other methods of contraception Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A & B are correct The image mentioned here is of the female condom. It is a barrier method of contraception. It prevents pregnancy and STDs, including HIV/AIDS, controlled by women and can be used even during menstruation. The failure rate of female condoms is about 5-21 per hundred women per year, whereas that of Combined OCPs is 0.3 per hundred women per year. So, female condoms have a higher failure rate. Female condom is made up of polyurethane sift thin plastic. It has two rings and is placed inside the vagina before sexual intercourse. It is relatively expensive as compared to other methods of contraception So, only Statements A & B are correct

questions.text: Which of the following contraceptives give additional protection from STD?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Condom The condom acts as a physical barrier. It covers the penis and protects the wearer’s partner from the deposition of semen in the vagina, thus preventing conception and the transmission of sexually transmitted infections. Spermicide jellies, foams, creams, contain surface active agents that damage the sperm cell membrane and inhibit oxygen uptake by perms and kill them. It, however, does not provide any protection against STDs. Oral Contraceptives offer couples a wide range of options for delaying, spacing, and limiting births. Oral contraceptives are safe, effective, and reversible methods of contraception however, they do not protect a woman from HIV or other Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs). Women using oral contraceptives must use condoms to prevent HIV or other STIs.

questions.text: Disadvantages of condoms are all EXCEPT-

options.label: A
options.text: Chances of accidental spillage of semen during sex

options.label: D
options.text: Chances of tear of slipping during sex

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Protection against STDs Advantages of condoms are: Easily available Safe and inexpensive Easy to use No side effects Provides protection against STDs Disadvantages of condom are: May slip off or tear during coitus due to incorrect use Interferes with sex sensation locally. The main limitation of condoms as a contraceptive is that many men do not use them regularly or carefully, even when the risk of unwanted pregnancy or sexually transmitted disease is high.

questions.text: The following statements are true about the contraceptive device given in the Image below, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Absolute contraindication of the contraceptive device is suspected pregnancy and PID

options.label: B
options.text: It is effective as a post-coital contraceptive, if Inserted within 3-5 days of unprotected intercourse

options.label: C
options.text: Levonorgestrel releasing IUD has an effective life of 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: Cu- T 200 is a third-generation IUD

questions.correct_answer: D. Cu- T 200 is a third-generation IUD
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cu- T 200 is a third-generation IUD The given Image is of INTRA-UTERINE DEVICES used as a Contraceptive device. Option: A . Absolute contraindication of the contraceptive device is suspected pregnancy, PID, vaginal bleeding, cancer of the cervix and uterus, and previous ectopic pregnancy. Option: B . It is effective as a post-coital contraceptive, if Inserted within 3-5 days of unprotected intercourse Option: C . Levonorgestrel releasing IUD has an effective life of 10 years Option: D . Cu- T 200 is a second generation IUD's

questions.text: For a woman to be an ideal candidate for Intra Uterine Contraceptive devices, she should meet the following criteria EXCEPT -

options.label: A
options.text: Should have borne at least 2 children

options.label: B
options.text: Has no history of Pelvic disease

questions.correct_answer: A. Should have borne at least 2 children
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Should have borne at least 2 children The Planned Parenthood Federation of America (PPFA) has described the ideal IUD candidate as a woman: i. who has borne at least one child (Option A) ii. has no history of pelvic disease (Option B) iii. has normal menstrual periods(Option D) iv. Is willing to check the IUD tail v. Has access to follow-up and treatment of potential problems, and vi. Is in a monogamous relationship (Option C)

questions.text: A 28-year-old female delivered a baby by normal vaginal delivery. A convenient time for Post-puerperal IUCD insertion is –

options.label: A
options.text: During the First week after delivery before the woman leaves the hospital

questions.explanation:
Solution:

6-8 weeks after delivery After the delivery of a baby, IUCD insertion can be taken up during the first week after delivery before the woman leaves the hospital: Immediate Postpartum insertion. Immediate postpartum insertion is associated with a high expulsion rate, and there is a greater risk of perforation during this time. A convenient time for IUCD insertion is 6-8 weeks after delivery: Post-Puerperal insertion. Post-puerperal insertion can be combined with a follow-up examination of the woman and her child.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female seeking contraceptive advice goes to a health facility. She has vaginal bleeding of undiagnosed etiology. Which of the following contraceptive methods will be absolutely contraindicated in her-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intra Uterine Devices The client with vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology should not be given IUCD as the bleeding may be due to carcinoma of the cervix or uterus or pelvic infection. Inserting IUCD in such women may aggravate the condition and cause complications. Absolute Contraindications to the use of IUCDs are- Suspected Pregnancy Pelvic Inflammatory Disease Vaginal bleeding of undiagnosed etiology Cancer of cervix, uterus or adnexia and other pelvic tumor Previous ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A lady visited CHC for IUCD insertion. Which of the following IUCD is available under the National Family Planning Programme in India-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both 2 & 3 Currently, there are two types of IUCDs available under the National Family Planning Programme: IUCD 380- A, effective up to 10 years IUCD 375, effective up to 5 years Key features of IUCD 380A and IUCD 375 Feature IUCD 380 A IUCD 375 Shape T shaped device Inverted U shaped device Dimensions 3.6 cm long and 3.2 cm wide 3.5 cm long and 1.8 cm wide with 5 stubs on each side on the 'U' Copper Wire Vertical stem and horizontal arms are wound with copper wire Only vertical stem is wound with copper wire Surface Area of Copper 380 sq. mm 375 sq. mm Material of the Strings Polyethylene strings Monofilament nylon threads Colour of strings White Fluorescent Green Duration 10 years from the day of insertion 5 years from the day of insertion Content in the sterile packet 1. IUCD 380 A 2. Insertion tube -Clear tube to guide the loaded IUCD through cervical os into the uterus 3. Cervical guard/blue length gauge on insertion tube - To set the appropriate measurement of the insertion tube corresponding to the length of the uterus and to ensure that the arms of the T unfold in the proper direction (horizontal plane) when they are released from the insertion tube 4. Measurement strip It is used to set the blue length gauge to the appropriate measurement, obtained by sounding the uterus. 5. Plunger rod - White rod, put inside the insertion tube containing loaded IUCD and the tip of the rod remains just below the IUCD. 1. IUCD 375 2. Insertion tube - Clear tube to guide the IUCD through the cervical os into the uterus 3. Cervical guard/ blue length gauge on insertion tube To set the appropriate measurement of the insertion tube corresponding to the length of the uterus 4. Measurement strip It is - used to set the blue length gauge to the appropriate measurement, obtained by sounding the uterus. 5. No plunger rod- There is no plunger rod in IUCD 375. The vertical stem is preloaded, and the side arms do not require loading into the insertion tube. The arms are flexible to adapt to the shape of the cervical canal.

questions.text: CORRECT statement about the device shown in the image:

options.label: B
options.text: It has a coating of 380 mm of copper

options.label: C
options.text: It gives additional protection from HIV infection

options.label: D
options.text: It is absolutely contraindicated in breastfeeding women

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a 3rd generation IUCD
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a 3rd generation IUCD The image shown here is of Progestasert. Option:B. It is a 3rd generation, hormone-releasing IUCD filled with 38 mg of progesterone. Option:C. It has no coating of copper, and neither it gives protection against HIV or other Option:D. Breastfeeding mothers may use this device safely.

questions.text: Side Effects associated with the contraceptive shown in the image are all EXCEPT
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amenorrhea The image shown here is of Copper T 380 A, Intra Uterine Contraceptive Device. Following are the side effects associated with the use of this device: Bleeding Pain abdomen Pelvic infection Uterine perforation Ectopic Pregnancy Spontaneous Expulsion

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lippes loop Lippes Loop is a double-$ shaped device made of polyethylene, a plastic material that is non-toxic, non-tissue reactive, and extremely durable. It contains a small amount of barium sulphate to allow X-ray observation. The Loop has attached threads or "tails" made of fine nylon, which project into the vagina after insertion. The tail can be easily felt, reassuring the user that the Loop is in its place. The tail also makes it easy to remove the Loop when desired. The Lippes Loop exists in four sizes A, B, C, and D, the latter being the largest. A larger-sized device usually has a greater anti-fertility effect and a lower expulsion rate but a higher removal rate because of side effects such as pain and bleeding. The larger Loops (C and D) are more suitable for multiparous women

questions.text: If the tail of IUCD is missing after 2 months of insertion, then which of the following step the client should take-

options.label: A
options.text: Should wait for the next period before coming to health facility

options.label: B
options.text: Should immediately come to the health facility & contact the service provider

options.label: C
options.text: Should not worry & plan with her husband for using another method after her next period

questions.correct_answer: B. Should immediately come to the health facility & contact the service provider
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Should immediately come to the health facility & contact the service provider The IUCD wearer should be counselled properly that she is supposed to check the threads or tail to be sure that IUCD is in the uterus. If she fails to locate the thread, then she must consult the doctor Reasons for missing tail could be either spontaneous expulsion or IUCD being displaced. It requires immediate medical attention as the device may migrate into the peritoneal cavity causing serious complications such as intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is using Oral Contraceptive pills since a year ago. All are the beneficial effects of oral contraceptive pills, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cerebral Thromboembolism Both the Royal College of General Practitioners and the Oxford Family Planning Association's long-term prospective studies of pill use in Britain have shown that using the pill may give protection against at least 6 diseases: I. Benign breast disorders, including fibrocystic disease and fibroadenoma, II. Ovarian cysts, III. Iron-deficiency anaemia, IV. Pelvic inflammatory disease, V. Ectopic pregnancy, and VI. Ovarian cancer.

questions.text: Oral pills are contraindicated in all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pelvic inflammatory disease Oral Pills Are Rather Indicated For Pid The Contraindications For Oral Pills: Absolute: Cancer of the breast and genitals; liver disease; previous or present history of thromboembolism; cardiac abnormalities; congenital hyperlipidaemia; undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding. Special problems requiring medical surveillance: Age over 40 years; smoking and age over 35 years; mild hypertension; chronic renal disease; epilepsy; migraine; nursing mothers in the first 6 months; diabetes mellitus; gall bladder disease; history of infrequent bleeding, amenorrhoea, etc

questions.text: Contraception of choice in a newly married couple is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

OCP Contraceptives Progesterone-only pills are advocated usually in older women (age > 40 yrs), lactating women in the first 6 months of lactation or even in young women with the risk of neoplasia. But these pills could not become very popular due to poor cycle control and risk of pregnancy and definitely not a contraceptive of choice in newly married couples. (option a) OCPs are by far the contraceptive of choice in a young newly married couple wherein the wife does not suffer from any of the contraindications. The single most significant benefit of the pill is its almost 100 % effectiveness in preventing pregnancy and thereby removing the anxiety about the risk of unplanned pregnancy. Another advantage of OCPs is that the contraceptive effect is fully reversible and nearly 98% of women conceive within 3 months of discontinuation of these pills which is most desirable in newly married couples. Although barrier methods (however the question does not specify it as condoms) and to be more precise, condoms are the most commonly used method of contraception worldwide, its failure rate (ranging from 4 to 14 per HWY ) is very high if not used appropriately, which precludes its usefulness in a newly married couple. (option c) In 1985, the American College of Obstetricians & Gynaecologists stated that IUDs are “not recommended for women who have not had children or who have multiple partners, because of the risk of PID and possible infertility.” (option d)

questions.text: Contraceptive of choice in lactating female:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Progesterone only pill Progesterone-only pills are advocated usually in older women (age > 40 yrs), lactating women in the first 6 months of lactation , or even in young women with the risk of neoplasia. But these pills could not become very popular due to poor cycle control and risk of pregnancy, but they are definitely a contraceptive of choice in lactating women. (option c) OCPs are by far the contraceptive of choice in a young, newly married couple wherein the wife does not suffer from any of the contraindications, but combined pills are not recommended during lactation as it is known to suppress lactation. The single most significant benefit of the pill is its almost 100 % effectiveness in preventing pregnancy and thereby removing the anxiety about the risk of unplanned pregnancy. Another advantage of OCPs is that the contraceptive effect is fully reversible and nearly 98% of women conceive within 3 months of discontinuation of these pills, which is most desirable in newly married couples. Barrier methods like female condoms, diaphragm, or vaginal sponges because of their high cost, limited availability, acceptability, and high failure rate, have never gained popularity. Lactational amenorrhea is never a recommended method for contraception because of its very high failure rate, although it has no side effects.

questions.text: All of the following are absolute contraindications of Combined Oral Contraceptives EXCEPT-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholelithiasis Absolute Contraindications to the use of combined pills are: i. Past or present thromboembolic disorder ii. Coronary artery disease iii. Known or suspected breast carcinoma iv. Endometrial or any estrogen-dependent neoplasia v. Pregnancy vi. Hepatic adenoma vii. Carcinoma or benign liver tumors viii. Undiagnosed abnormal genital tract bleeding ix. Markedly impaired liver function tests Relative Contraindications to the use of combined pills are: i. Age > 35 years ii. Migraine iii. Smoker iv. Depression v. Hypertension vi. Diabetes vii. Asthma viii. Ulcerative colitis ix. Gallbladder disease So, Cholelithiasis or gallstone is a relative contraindication to the use of COCs and not an absolute contraindication.

questions.text: True about the contraceptive shown in the image:

options.label: A
options.text: Supplied at a cost of ₹5 per packet by the government of India

options.label: D
options.text: It may increase the risk of osteoporosis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

It has 21 hormone-containing pills The image shown here is of Mala-N , which is a combined oral contraceptive supplied free of cost by the Government of India through all PHCs, urban family welfare centres, etc. It contains Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and Ethinyl estradiol 0.03 mg. It contains 21 ‘active’ (hormonal) and 7 ‘inactive’ (non-hormonal, contains ferrous fumarate) pills. One of the non-contraceptive benefits of COCs is protection against osteoporosis.

questions.text: Incorrect statement about the drug shown in the above image

options.label: B
options.text: It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator

options.label: D
options.text: Should be taken twice a week for the first 3 months and once a week after that

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contraindicated during breastfeeding The image shown here is of a non-hormonal oral contraceptive pill ‘Chhaya .’ It contains Centchroman. It was developed indigenously by the Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow. It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator, which acts by increasing the movement of the fertilized ovum through the fallopian tubes to the endometrial cavity before it is ready for implantation. It is safe for lactating women and is not known to cause any side effects except for prolongation of menstrual cycles in a few women. It causes a prompt return to fertility and can be given to women of all age groups. It Should be taken twice a week for the first 3 months and once a week after that.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on Combined oral contraceptive pills, missed 2 pills in the first week. However, she takes the missed pill after 12 hours. What is the correct step she should take to avoid contraception?

options.label: B
options.text: Continue the scheduled pills and use condoms for the next 7 days.

options.label: C
options.text: Continue the hormonal pills as scheduled and discard the non-hormonal pills

options.label: D
options.text: Discard all the pills and use an alternate method of contraception for this month.

questions.correct_answer: B. Continue the scheduled pills and use condoms for the next 7 days.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continue the scheduled pills and use condoms for the next 7 days. Management of missed pills Missed pills How to manage How to continue Backup method 1 or 2 pills in the first week Take the missed pill as soon as she remembers Continue the scheduled pill Not required If takes the missed pill after 12 hours Continue the scheduled pill Use a condom for first 7 days 3 or more pills in the first 14 days Take the first pill as soon as possible Continue the scheduled pill Use a condom for first 7 days/ consider ECP if had sex in last 72 hours 3 or more pills in the third week Take the first pill as soon as possible Continue the hormonal pills as scheduled. Discard the non-hormonal pills. Start a new pack the very next day. Use a condom for the first 7 days/ consider ECP if had sex in the last 72 hours. Missed any non-hormonal pills Discard the missed pill. Continue the scheduled pill. Start the new pack as usual Not required

questions.text: Oral Contraceptive Pill suitable for a lactating mother within 6-months after delivery is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mini Pill Progesterone-only pills also called as mini-pills , contain a small amount of progesterone and no estrogen. They are indicated for women > 40 years of age or who are lactating and have not completed 6 months after delivery. Mala D & Mala N are Combined oral Pills and are relatively contraindicated in women who are breastfeeding their children, up to 6 months post-partum. Antara is an injectable hormonal contraceptive & not an oral contraceptive pill.

questions.text: A couple had unprotected intercourse 52 hours ago. They didn’t want any further Pregnancy, so they used Post-coital Contraceptives. All of the given can be used as Post-coital Contraceptives, except:

options.label: A
options.text: IUD: Insert IUD, if acceptable, especially a copper device to be used within 5 days.

options.label: C
options.text: Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg tablet 2 doses, 12 hours apart

questions.correct_answer: B. Estrogen pill 50mg once within 72 hour
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Estrogen pill 50mg once within 72 hour Post-coital (or "morning after") contraception is recommended within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Two methods are available: IUD: The simplest technique is inserting an IUD, especially a copper device, within 5 days if acceptable. Hormonal : More often, a hormonal method may be preferable. In India, Levonorgestrel 0. 75 mg tablet is approved for emergency contraception. It is used as one tablet of 0. 75 mg within 72 hours of unprotected sex and the 2nd tablet after 12 hours of 1st dose. or Two oral contraceptive pills containing 50 mcg of ethinyl estradiol within 72 hours after intercourse and the same dose after 12 hours. or Four oral contraceptive pills containing 30 or 35 mcg of ethinyl estradiol within 72 hours and 4 tablets after 12 hours. or Mifepristone 10 mg once within 72 hours.

questions.text: A couple came with apprehension 4 days after unprotected sex seeking contraception. Which of the following emergency contraceptive method may be given to this couple-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IUCD insertion Intrauterine Contraceptive Device can be inserted within 5 days of unprotected intercourse. CuT is the best post-coital contraceptive due to its lowest failure rate. In the Yuzpe method or Combined estrogen-progesterone regimen, 1st dose is taken as early as possible but within 72 hours of unprotected sex. The second dose should be taken 12 hours after 1st dose. Two tablets of Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg 12 hours apart may be prescribed within 72 hours of unprotected sex. Mifepristone 10mg once within 72 hours can be given within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Since already 4 days have passed, these regimens cannot be given.

questions.text: A couple reported to OPD within 72 hours of unprotected sexual intercourse seeking emergency contraception. Which of the following regimen is INCORRECT with respect to emergency contraception-

options.label: C
options.text: 4 OCPs containing 30-35 mcg of estradiol and 4 tablets after 12 hours

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg one tablet Post-coital or morning-after contraception is recommended within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Two methods are available: IUCD- Insertion of CuT within 5 days Hormonal- Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg 2 tablets 12 hours apart within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse 4 OCPs containing 30-35 mcg of estradiol and 4 tablets after 12 hours Mifepristone 10 mg once within 72 hours Yuzpe method (Combined estrogen progesterone regimen): 2 doses 12 hours apart within 72 hours of unprotected sex

questions.text: The most common cause for failure of contraception after vasectomy is-

options.label: B
options.text: Improper history taking of the client

questions.correct_answer: A. Misidentification of the vas deferens
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Misidentification of the vas deferens The failure rate of vasectomy is generally low, 0.15 per 100 person-years. The most common cause of failure is due to mistaken identification of the vas. That is, instead of the vas, some other structure in the spermatic cord, such as a thrombosed vein or thickened lymphatic, has been taken Histological confirmation has, therefore, been recommended on all vasectomy specimens by developed countries. But a simpler method is adopted in developing countries wherein microscopic examination of a smear is prepared by gentle squeezing of the vas on a glass slide and staining with Wright’s stain. The vas can be identified by the presence of columnar epithelial cells that line the lumen of the vas. Other causes of failure may be due to spontaneous recanalization of the vas.

questions.text: As per NFHS – V, the most widely practiced method of contraception in India is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tubectomy As per National Family Health Survey – V data, female sterilization is the most widely practiced method of contraception (37.9%). Condom use is 9.5% Oral Contraceptive Pill use - 5.4% IUCD - 2.1% Injectable contraceptive – 0.6% Male sterilization – 0.3%

questions.text: Read the following post-operative advice given to a client after vasectomy and mark the correct option- A. Use contraceptive for at least the next 30 ejaculations B. Avoid taking a bath for at least 24 hours C. To have stitches removed on the 25th day after operation D. Complete bed rest for at least 15 days Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A & B are correct To ensure normal healing of the wound and to ensure the success of the vasectomy operation, the patient should be given the following advice- Use contraceptives until aspermia has been established ( at least 30 ejaculations) Avoid taking bath for at least 24 hours after the operation To have stitches removed on the 5th day after the operation No need for complete bed rest, however, avoid cycling or lifting heavy weights for 15 days To wear a T-bandage or scrotal support (langot) for 15 days and to keep the site clean and dry.

questions.text: A patient returns to CHC with a complaint of pain & swelling in the testis. Clinically there is a mass which is hard & is of 7 mm approximately. He was diagnosed to have developed ‘sperm granules’. It is a complication of –
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vasectomy 'Sperm granules’ are one of the few complications that may arise after vasectomy. It is caused by the accumulation of sperm. They appear 10-14 days after the operation. The most frequent symptoms are pain and swelling. Clinically, the mass is hard, and the average size is approximately 7 mm. Sperm granules may provide a medium through which re-anastomosis of the severed vas can occur. The sperm granules eventually subside. It has been reported that using metal clips to the vas may reduce or eliminate this problem.

questions.text: Which of the following is included in the natural method of family planning?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Natural family planning methods: It includes 3 methods . Option: A. Basal body temperature method: there is a rise in basal body temperature at the time of ovulation due to an increase in the production of progesterone. It indicated the occurrence of ovulation. The temperature rises by 0.3 to 0.5 degrees The body temperature does not rise when there is no ovulation Option: B. Billings method: also known as cervical mucus method or ovulation method. It is based on the observation of changes in the characteristic of cervical mucus. At the time of ovulation, the cervical mucus becomes watery and clear as raw egg white. After ovulation, the mucus thickens and lessens in quantity. Option: C. Symptothermic method: this method combines the temperature, cervical mucus, and calendar technique for the identification of the fertile period.

questions.text: Some degree of protection against pregnancy is achieved in the early months after childbirth. Many couples exploit this period for sexual intercourse for contraception. This method of contraception is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lactational amenorrhoea method Some degree of protection against pregnancy is achieved in the early months after childbirth provided the women if exclusively breastfeeding her child. This is known as lactational amenorrhoea Exclusive breastfeeding suppresses woman’s fertility in early months after delivery due to an increase in prolactin, which inhibits ovulation. Lactational amenorrhoea is effective until her menstrual period has not returned since delivery, if she is breastfeeding exclusively and on-demand, both during day and night and the baby is less than 6 months old. By and large, by 6 months after childbirth, about 20-50% of women are menstruating and are in need of conception. Billings’s method: There occur some changes in the consistency of cervical mucus during the menstrual cycle, due to hormonal variations, which can be observed by touch or by toilet paper. Appearance of mucus marks the fertile period, which is usually 4-7 days prior to ovulation. Mucus has an ‘egg white’ consistency, and the couple may abstain from sex during this period. Calender method: It takes into account the duration of the cycle in the last one year. To estimate the fertile period, subtract 18 from the total duration of the shortest recorded cycle and 11 from that of the longest recorded cycle in the last one year. Yuzpe method: Yuzpe method is an emergency contraception regimen wherein 2 doses of combined estrogen-progesterone 12 hours apart within 72 hours of unprotected sex are given.

questions.text: Out of the following methods of contraception, the one with the highest failure rate is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coitus interruptus The failure rate of condoms range from 2 -14 HWY for male condom and 5-21 HWY for female condoms. - IUCDs have a failure rate of 1 per hundred women year in the first year of insertion. Over 10 years of use, the failure rate has been seen to be 2 per hundred women per year. Coitus interruptus is a method in which a male partner withdraws before ejaculation and thereby tries to prevent deposition of semen into the vagina. The chief drawback of this method is that the pre-coital secretion of the male may contain sperm and may cause pregnancy. Hence it has a failure rate of as high as 25%, so not advised. Coitus interruptus is a method in which a male partner withdraws before ejaculation and thereby tries to prevent deposition of semen into the vagina. The chief drawback of this method is that the pre-coital secretion of the male may contain sperm and may cause pregnancy. Hence it has a failure rate of as high as 25%, so not advised. Calendar rhythm method takes into account the duration of cycles in the last one year. To estimate the fertile period, subtract 18 from the total duration of the shortest recorded cycle and 11 from the longest recorded cycle in the last one year. This will give the fertile period where chances of pregnancy are highest. It offers effective contraception only if the couple is motivated and understands the implications of failure which amounts to 9 per Hundred women per year.
